postsData.name:
Tanner Smith
Tanner Smith
postsData.content:
Stop educating your customers.

They already know what they need.

Nobody wants another lesson about your industry.

They want to know if you understand their problem.

I’ve worked with brands who wasted time explaining what they do.

Instead of showing they understand who they serve.

Here's what your customers really want to know:

• Have you solved their exact problem before?
• Do you speak their language?
• Can you name their pain points?

Anything beyond that is noise.

Nike doesn't teach you about shoes.

Neither does Apple explain computers.

Unless you've invented time travel, your industry isn't new.

Your customers aren't clueless.

They just need to see themselves in your story.

Focus on connection, not education.

comments.commentText: This is well said which as few as words possible. Love this!!!

postsData.commentAdded: Spot on! Its all about empathy and connection. Understanding your audiences needs leads to genuine relationships and lasting success.

Jeff Roberts
Jeff Roberts
postsData.content:
Goldman Sachs recently announced changes to its management committee, reflecting a shift in leadership under CEO David Solomon. According to Business Insider, this reshuffle signals an effort to navigate challenges in its investment banking division and reposition the firm for future growth.

Leadership transitions at this level are always complex. They're an opportunity to bring fresh perspectives but also a moment of risk if alignment isn't clear. For leaders, the key takeaway is this: Strategic leadership isn't just about managing people—it's about steering the organization through uncertainty while keeping long-term goals in focus.

How do leadership changes impact organizational momentum? Are they always a sign of reinvention, or can they cause instability?

Read more on Business Insider:
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Leadership changes can drive innovation but also pose risks. It’s crucial to maintain clarity and alignment for sustained growth.

postsData.name:
Michael Walker Ed.D.
Michael Walker Ed.D.
postsData.content:
𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝗳 𝗮 𝘀𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗸𝗲𝗻𝗱 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝘀𝗲𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘂𝗽 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮 𝘀𝗺𝗼𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿, 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗱𝘂𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗸?

𝗪𝗲𝗲𝗸𝗲𝗻𝗱𝘀 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗳𝗲𝗲𝗹 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗿—errands, responsibilities, the never-ending to-do list.

𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀𝗻’𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗻. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝗱𝗲 to make space for it.

𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝘀𝗻’𝘁 𝗮 𝗹𝘂𝘅𝘂𝗿𝘆; 𝗶𝘁’𝘀 𝗮 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆. Studies show that intentional rest improves creativity, decision-making, and overall performance. In fact, research from the University of Illinois found that brief mental breaks can boost focus and productivity.

So this weekend, 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗼:
 Reflect – What went well this week? What didn’t? Adjust accordingly.
 Recharge – Success is a marathon, not a sprint. Rest is productive.
 Learn – Read, listen, or watch something that expands your mind.
 Plan – Set yourself up to hit the ground running on Monday.

You do have 𝗱𝗲𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗿𝗲𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 about how you use your time. Will you make the decision to build in restoration?

 𝗦𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗱𝗼 𝘁𝗼 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗴𝗲 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗸𝗲𝗻𝗱𝘀.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Taking time to reflect and recharge is essential for sustained productivity. Looking forward to a restorative weekend ahead!

postsData.name:
Anisha Jain
Anisha Jain
postsData.content:
Success isn’t achieved through avoiding failure.

It's the result of learning from every setback.

5 Lessons from Famous Failures:

1. Michael Jordan’s Missed Shots

Jordan missed 12,345 shots in his career.
These misses taught him resilience.

Every missed shot was a lesson.
He kept working, never giving up.

2. Federer’s Win Rate

Federer has a 54% win rate.
Even legends lose often.

He studies his losses.
Improves from each one.

3. Serena’s Lost Finals

Serena lost 10 finals.
These losses taught her stamina and strategy.

She learned to adapt.
She persisted through setbacks.

4. Sugar Ray Robinson’s Early Defeats

Robinson faced early defeats.
These stripped him of arrogance.

He sharpened his focus.
Each defeat made him stronger.

5. Ronaldo’s Penalty Misses

Ronaldo missed penalties.
He learned to ignore pressure.

Every miss was a training.
He kept pushing forward.

Greatness isn’t born from wins.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Every setback is a stepping stone to success. Learning from failures is what truly shapes our journey toward greatness!

postsData.name:
Shashwat Srivastava
Shashwat Srivastava
postsData.content:
️ Fusion Power: The Future is Here! 

 China's Artificial Sun Breaks Records!
China’s Experimental Advanced Superconducting Tokamak (EAST) has set a groundbreaking milestone, sustaining high-confinement plasma for 1,066 seconds at an incredible 100 million°C!  This achievement marks a significant leap toward limitless clean energy.

 India’s Innovation in Fusion Research
Meanwhile, India is making remarkable progress with SST-1, a superconducting tokamak at the Institute for Plasma Research (IPR). Equipped with advanced superconducting magnets, SST-1 achieves plasma discharges of ~500 ms with currents exceeding 75,000 A at a central field of 1.5 T. 

 Why This Matters
Fusion energy promises zero-carbon, limitless, and sustainable power, reshaping the future of global energy. With China and India leading the charge, the race for commercial fusion energy is heating up! 

 What are your thoughts on fusion energy? Is this the dawn of a new energy era? Drop your insights below!
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting times for fusion energy! 🌟 With advancements in China and India, we’re closer to a sustainable energy future. Thoughts on implications for global energy?

postsData.name:
Manuj Aggarwal
Manuj Aggarwal
postsData.content:
Jeff Sloan, the retired CEO of Global Payments Inc., is a transformative leader in the fintech industry with a career spanning nearly three decades. 

Renowned for his decisive leadership and innovative vision, Jeff spearheaded Global Payments' historic merger with TSYS in 2019, earning the company a coveted spot on the Fortune 500 by 2021.

Under his guidance, Global Payments' stock achieved a compounded annual growth rate of 16.5%, outpacing industry peers and the S&P 500.

Before joining Global Payments in 2010 and ascending to the CEO role in 2013, Jeff led the Financial Technology Group at Goldman Sachs, orchestrating landmark transactions that shaped the payments industry.

Jeff's insights into scaling businesses, navigating complex mergers, and delivering exceptional shareholder value make him a sought-after voice in financial technology and leadership.

Join us as Jeff shares his journey from investment banking to redefining fintech leadership, lessons learned from his storied career, and his vision for the future of innovation in financial services.
postsData.commentAdded: Inspiring to see how Jeffs leadership reshaped fintech! Excited to learn from his experiences and insights on innovation in financial services.

Dheeraj Sharma

postsData.content:
Your skills can open doors, but your behavior determines how long you stay inside.


Bold Opinion:-
Talent may set you apart, but your behavior is what truly makes you stand out.

I once met two equally skilled professionals. One was respected for their kindness and integrity, the other struggled due to their attitude. It was a reminder that behavior shapes success. Here’s how to refine yours:

1. Be respectful, always. How you treat others matters.


2. Stay humble. Growth comes from learning.


3. Communicate with empathy. Understand before reacting.


4. Lead with integrity. Trust is earned, not given.

What behavior do you think defines true success?
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Skills can get you in, but its your actions that keep you there. Integrity and respect are key to lasting success. What values guide you?

postsData.name:
Amir Tabch
Amir Tabch
postsData.content:
You know what’s worse than hearing the truth? Finding out way too late that someone lied to you. Imagine walking into an important meeting, chest puffed, ready to deliver your revolutionary, industry-shaking idea… only for the entire room to go silent. The kind of silence that makes you check if your mic is on. The kind of silence that signals you’re about to be eviscerated.

Turns out, your “brilliant” idea? Your team thought it was horrible, but instead of telling you, they just nodded politely like bobbleheads. Congratulations. You’re now the corporate equivalent of a contestant on a talent show whose family swore they could sing—until Simon Cowell opened his mouth.

This is why, as a leader, I’d rather tell you the truth & have you hate me than sugarcoat a lie just to be liked. & I expect the same in return. Because a team built on truth is a team that wins.

Now, before anyone accuses me of being heartless, research backs me up. A JPSP study found that people who give direct, constructive feedback are more respected in the long run than those who avoid difficult conversations.

This means that leaders who sugarcoat, avoid confrontation, or play the “nice guy” card aren't doing anyone a favor. In fact, they’re sabotaging their own teams. If no one trusts you to be honest, you’re just a figurehead, not a leader.

Look, I get it. No one likes to be the bearer of bad news. It’s easier to tell someone, “Great job!” than to say, “Your strategy is as effective as a screen door on a submarine.” But what happens when you choose being liked over being honest?

• Short-term relief, long-term disaster – You avoid an awkward conversation today but set the stage for bigger failures tomorrow.

• Loss of credibility – Once people realize you sugarcoat everything, your words carry as much weight as a fortune cookie.

• Mediocrity festers – Without honest feedback, no one grows. No one improves. & soon, your team becomes a comfortable puddle of meh.

Here’s the catch: If I expect to give the truth, I expect to receive the truth. That means if I have a terrible idea, I need my team to say:

• “Boss, this is terrible.”
• “You might want to rethink that.”
• “We love you, but this isn’t it.”

& not just when it's convenient. Not just when I ask for it. I need people who are willing to walk into my office, stare me in the eye, & say:

“Listen, I know you think this is genius, but it’s giving ‘midlife crisis energy,’ & we need to course-correct before it’s too late.” Because if I’m running full speed toward a cliff, I expect my team to yell, “STOP!”—not cheer me on.

At the end of the day, I can either tell people what they want to hear & watch them fail—or tell them what they need to hear & help them grow.

So, hate me if you must. Dislike me if it makes you sleep better at night. But know this: When you work with me, you will always know exactly where you stand. Because the truth might sting, but a well-placed lie? That’ll bury you.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Honest feedback is crucial for growth. Let’s embrace the truth and build stronger teams together! 🌟 #Leadership #Teamwork

postsData.content:
Over the past 3 years - I have thought a lot about
the Human Element.

Since September of 2022,
I have taught Creative Professionals
how to understand and integrate
GenAI in their Creative Workflow
while retaining the Human Element.

As my good friendsaid,

"The beauty of integrating AI into our work is that it complements what we already know. When you are ready to dive in, AI will be more accessible, user-friendly, and tailored to meet professionals exactly where they are."

AI is an amplifier.
The Human Element (all the LIFE experiences that have shaped who you are, what you know, your WORK experience and PERSONAL perspective) is the full embodiment of... you.

Here is to celebrating the combination of both...
AI + the Human Element

postsData.name:
Geetika Saigal
Geetika Saigal
postsData.content:
Your Brand Is Boring Without a Story
Here’s How to Fix It:

Most people think branding is about colors, logos, and a fancy website.

But let me tell you something… branding is storytelling.

You can have the best-looking brand in the world, but if your story doesn’t connect, no one will care.

Here are 3 storytelling tips that will make your brand unforgettable:

1️⃣ Stop Talking About You, Start Talking About Them

Nobody cares about your company’s journey until they see themselves in it. Make your customer the hero, and show how you help them win.

2️⃣ Show, Don’t Just Tell

Saying “We provide the best service” is boring. Instead, tell a story: “Last week, a client came to us frustrated after wasting thousands on the wrong strategy.

In two weeks, we turned things around, and they finally saw real results.” Now, that’s powerful.

3️⃣ Make It Personal

People connect with people, not businesses. Share your struggles, your wins, your real journey. The more human your brand feels, the stronger the connection.

 P.S. I’ve built brands through storytelling for years, and trust me, this works. If you’re ready to build a brand people actually remember, DM me.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Branding is all about connection. Great tips on making stories relatable and personal—time to captivate our audience! 🌟

postsData.name:
Garett Moreau 🇺🇸
Garett Moreau 🇺🇸
postsData.content:
BANNED IN ITALY: Italy’s data protection authority has restricted access to DeepSeek within Italy, due to inadequate details on how it manages user personal data.

Specifically, the authority sought clarification on the types of personal data collected via DeepSeek’s web and mobile platforms.

This included the following: the sources of this data, the purposes for collecting it, the legal grounds for processing, and whether the data was being stored in its home country.

On January 30, 2025, the Garante released a statement explaining that the decision to block was made because DeepSeek’s responses were deemed “completely insufficient.”

DeepSeek did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for a comment.
postsData.commentAdded: This raises crucial concerns about data privacy and transparency! Its vital for companies to prioritize user data protection.

postsData.name:
Mario Hernandez
Mario Hernandez
postsData.content:
Nonprofits Need to Increase Their Luck Surface Area:


Most nonprofits don’t fail because they don’t care enough.

They fail because they rely on hope instead of systems.

They wait for the “right donor” to show up.

They chase the “perfect grant” that takes months to secure.

They bank on a “viral moment” to suddenly change their fate.

That’s not how luck works.

Luck isn’t magic. It’s math.

The bigger your luck surface area, the more opportunities you attract.

Here’s how nonprofits can stack the odds in their favor:

1. Stop Being a Best-Kept Secret

Most nonprofits talk to the same tight-knit circle:

Existing donors, impact reports, and industry conferences.

Your future supporters aren’t in those rooms.

Get loud. Be where attention already exists:

→ Twitter threads about your boldest insights.
→ LinkedIn posts that challenge the status quo.
→ Podcasts where your mission reaches fresh ears.

More visibility = More serendipity.

2. Build a Magnet, Not a Megaphone:

Most fundraising feels like pushing cold outreach, grant chasing, begging.

Instead, build assets that make support come to you:

A newsletter that shares high-value insights, not just impact reports.

A founder who writes publicly about lessons learned.

A community where supporters feel involved, not just asked.

Inbound > Outbound. Every time.

3. Make Non-Traditional Asks:

Most nonprofits ask for donations. But money isn’t the only fuel.

Ask for:

Distribution (Who can amplify your message?)

Tech Partnerships (What tools can 10x your efficiency?)

Corporate Integrations (How can companies bake giving into their model?)

Funding follows momentum. Create it first.

4. Adopt a Startup Mindset

Successful startups don’t just raise money. They scale.

They A/B test messaging.

They automate donor follow-ups.

They iterate based on real feedback.

Nonprofits? Many still send PDFs and cross their fingers.

Innovation isn’t a luxury. It’s survival.

5. Become Undeniable

The best way to increase your luck?
Be so good they can’t ignore you.

Nail your messaging

Show radical transparency

Create something that demands to be shared

Luck isn’t about waiting. It’s about working the system.

Build it. Expand it. Watch what happens.

With purpose and impact,
postsData.commentAdded: Love this perspective! By elevating visibility and embracing innovative strategies, nonprofits can truly turn luck into a lasting impact. Let’s get to work!

postsData.name:
Reid Hoffman
Reid Hoffman
postsData.content:
We're entering an era where computers are evolving from tools to collaborators, which will shift our mental models of work. Rather than just executing commands, AI will work alongside us—continuing to develop ideas and refine our projects even when we’re away.

Imagine spending an hour immersed in a project, then stepping away for dinner or sleep, only to return and find that your AI has been iterating on your work; it’s proactively identifying gaps, exploring new angles, and effectively acting as an extension of your own creativity. Of course, the technology isn’t perfect yet, but as with any major innovation, early challenges pave the way for improvements.

It’s easy to see the future as AI only, or Human only, but I believe the real winners will be those that blend human operators with AI co-pilots. This is part of the reason I wrote my new book, Superagency, to showcase the ways AI can become a force multiplier that enhances human productivity, unbound by the limits of our own time or focus.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! The synergy between AI and human creativity is the future. Excited to see how Superagency explores this evolution. #AI #Innovation

postsData.name:
Marc Mawhinney
Marc Mawhinney
postsData.content:
Instead of doing "discovery calls", or "strategy calls" (or let's be honest, sales calls), I prefer to do: 

"Value Calls"

The goal of my value call isn't to sell you into my program.

Don't get me wrong - if it's the right fit to do something together then great, but I enter it with the goal of learning what you're trying to accomplish and what's keeping you from it, and giving actionable advice on how to move things forward.

If I know I can help you I'll tell you how, if not I'll leave you better off than when you arrived on the call.

I've done some calls with people where it hasn't been the right fit, but I've sent them a resource to help them along, or given them a book recommendation, or referred them to someone who could help.

I've opened up space in my calendar to do more of these Value Calls, and you can book yours at the link in the comments!
postsData.commentAdded: Love this approach! Focusing on value first fosters genuine connections and trust. Excited to see how these calls transform discussions!

postsData.name:
Siddhant Garg
Siddhant Garg
postsData.content:
𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐭𝐨 𝐦𝐚𝐢𝐥 𝐚 𝐂𝐕 :

When asked to email your CV,
You should never send your CV alone without composing a proper email.

𝐄𝐱𝐚𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞:

To: [Email address of the company you’re applying to]
Subject: APPLICATION FOR THE POSITION OF [POSITION TITLE]

Email Body:

Dear [Employer/HR Manager],

I am writing to express my interest in the position of [Position Title] as advertised recently. My qualifications, skills, and experience align closely with your requirements for this role.

Please find my CV and supporting documents attached for your review. I would be delighted to discuss how I can contribute to your team and look forward to hearing from you soon about this exciting opportunity.

Kind regards,
[Your Full Name]

𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐓𝐞𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐬,

𝑻𝒐 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝑯𝒊𝒓𝒊𝒏𝒈 𝑴𝒂𝒏𝒂𝒈𝒆𝒓 :

Hi (First Name),
I saw your profile while looking up (Industry Name) recruiters on LinkedIn in (Name of Place).
I am a (Insert Job Title), (Add relevant information about your experience).
My main skills encompass (add skills).
Does that fit the type of roles you generally recruit for?
I would love to work for (add company name) as their vision and mission are in line with mine.
Let me know what you think, I’d love to talk.
Best,
(Your Name)

𝑻𝒉𝒆 𝑱𝒐𝒃 𝑺𝒆𝒆𝒌𝒆𝒓 :

Greetings, (First Name)
My name is (Name), and I am a (Insert Role).
I have been following your organization's work for a while now. (Add notable achievements of company)
I am very interested in working at (Insert something unique to the company).

(Insert some information about your experience)
If you have a second, I would love to discuss how my experience and skills can benefit your organization for the position of (Insert name of role).
(If there is no job posting, and you want to inquire about an opening then add the line mentioned below.)

I know you must be flooded with messages; but if there are any job openings for (Insert Role), I would be more than delighted to share why I might be a good fit.

Thank you and have an amazing day!
Best,
(Your Name)


 Important Notes:

1. Always attach your CV in PDF format for professionalism. Avoid sending it as a scanned document, screenshot, or image file.

2. Review your email carefully before sending to ensure there are no errors or typos.

3.Use Proper E-mail  address in your Name.

 hashtag
your network It is Useful for Job seekers

️ Followfor more valuable stuff
T

Credit -

 Remote jobs & Ats resume
postsData.commentAdded: Great tips on crafting the perfect CV email! A personal touch can make a big difference. Thanks for sharing these insights! #JobSeeking #CareerAdvice

postsData.content:
𝑫𝒆𝒆𝒑𝑺𝒆𝒆𝒌’𝒔 𝑨𝑰 𝑼𝒏𝒅𝒆𝒓 𝑰𝒏𝒗𝒆𝒔𝒕𝒊𝒈𝒂𝒕𝒊𝒐𝒏: 𝑷𝒐𝒔𝒔𝒊𝒃𝒍𝒆 𝑼𝒏𝒂𝒖𝒕𝒉𝒐𝒓𝒊𝒛𝒆𝒅 𝑼𝒔𝒆 𝒐𝒇 𝑶𝒑𝒆𝒏𝑨𝑰’𝒔 𝑻𝒆𝒄𝒉𝒏𝒐𝒍𝒐𝒈𝒚
In recent months, DeepSeek’s AI model, R1, has come under intense scrutiny over allegations that it may have been trained using OpenAI’s proprietary data—potentially without authorization. Several anomalies in DeepSeek’s responses, knowledge cutoffs, and internal reasoning processes suggest that the Chinese AI company might have leveraged OpenAI’s GPT-4 outputs in its development. If proven true, this could be one of the most significant cases of AI model replication in recent history, raising serious ethical and legal questions.
postsData.commentAdded: This raises crucial ethical questions in AI development. Transparency and collaboration are key to ensuring innovation respects all contributors.

postsData.name:
Michael Ocean
Michael Ocean
postsData.content:
From door-to-door scripts to enterprise frameworks: evolution of a sales professional


I recently had an awesome conversation with(Fractional Head of Sales for early stage startups, ex-Shopify, ex-Oracle, ex-IBM). He did something fascinating - demonstrated his exact door-to-door pitch from Vivint from 8 years ago, then broke down IBM's Global Sales School framework live on the show!


Key takeaways from our chat:

- Role-playing remains the #1 training method across organizations of all sizes
- Why understanding buyer personas matter more than product pitches
- How early-stage startups can learn from enterprise training programs (and vice versa)


The most fascinating part? Hearing Ryan literally reconstruct his sales evolution - from memorized scripts at Vivint to sophisticated frameworks at IBM. His example opening at IBM was gold: combining personal story (door-to-door experience) with business value to create instant credibility.


In the full episode, we covered:

- Vivint's intensive door-to-door training program
- IBM's legendary Global Sales School experience
- The stark differences between startup vs enterprise sales training
- Why understanding customer problems beats knowing product features
- Key mistakes founders make when hiring their first sales rep


One of the most fun & tactical episodes I've recorded.

Check out the full conversation in the comments
postsData.commentAdded: Incredible insights! Its fascinating how adaptable sales methods are across stages. Cant wait to listen to the full episode! 🎧 #SalesEvolution

Congratulations to our 2025 Award winners!

A heartfelt thank you to our speakers for making the evening truly special:

We also welcomed our incoming Board Chair,, as she was officially sworn in by Mayor.

 Thank you for being part of The Gold Standard. Until next year!
